sen.j: スサノオ（スサノヲ、スサノオノミコト）は、日本神話に登場する一柱の神 (神道)である。
sen.e: Susano (also known as SUSANO no Mikoto) was a deity (Shinto religion) appeared in Japanese Mythology.
Susano (also known as SUSANO no Mikoto) was a deity (Shinto religion) that appeared in Japanese mythology.
Susano (also known as Susano no Mikoto) was a deity (Shinto religion) that appeared in Japanese mythology.
sen.cmt: SUSANO→Susano 他の記事と合わせる。

sen.j: 『日本書紀』では素戔男尊、素戔嗚尊等、『古事記』では建速須佐之男命（たけはやすさのおのみこと、たてはやすさのおのみこと）、須佐乃袁尊、『出雲国風土記』では神須佐能袁命（かむすさのおのみこと）、神須佐能袁命などと表記する。
sen.e: His name was written in kanji as 素戔男尊 and 素戔嗚尊 in "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), 建速須佐之男命 (TAKEHAYASUSA no Onomikoto or TATEHAYASUSA no Onomikoto) and 須佐乃袁尊 (SUSANO no Mikoto) in "Kojiki" (Records of Ancient Matters), and 神須佐能袁命 (KAMUSUSA no Onomikoto) and 神須佐能袁命 in "Izumo no kuni fudoki" (Fudoki of Izumo no kuni).
sen.cmt: 漢字が焦点になっているため、訳文にも漢字を残しました。
sen.e: His name was written in kanji as 素戔男尊 and 素戔嗚尊 in "Nihon Shoki (Chronicles of Japan"), 建速須佐之男命 (TAKEHAYASUSA no Onomikoto or TATEHAYASUSA no Onomikoto) and 須佐乃袁尊 (SUSANO no Mikoto) in "Kojiki (Records of Ancient Matters"), and 神須佐能袁命 (KAMUSUSA no Onomikoto) and 神須佐能袁命 in "Izumo no kuni fudoki" (Fudoki of Izumo no kuni).

His name was written in kanji as 素戔男尊 and 素戔嗚尊 in "Nihon Shoki" (Chronicles of Japan), 建速須佐之男命 (Takehayasusa no Onomikoto or Tatehayasusa no Onomikoto) and 須佐乃袁尊 (Susano no Mikoto) in "Kojiki" (Records of Ancient Matters), and 神須佐能袁命 (Kamususa no Onomikoto) and 神須佐能袁命 in "Izumo no kuni fudoki" (Fudoki of Izumo no kuni).
sen.cmt: "の位置移動名前の表記（大文字部分）を他の記事に合わせ小文字に

sen.j: 牛頭天王と同一視されることもある。
sen.e: He was sometimes seen identical as Gozu Tenno (deity said to be the Indian god Gavagriva).
He was sometimes seen identical to Gozu Tenno (a deity said to be the Indian god Gavagriva).
He was sometimes seen identical to Gozu Tenno (a deity said to be the Indian god Gavagriva).

sen.j: 三貴子の末子に当たる。
sen.e: He was the youngest son of Mihashira no uzuno miko (three deities).
He was the youngest son of Mihashira no uzuno miko (three deities).
He was the youngest son of Mihashira no uzuno miko (three deities).

sen.j: その与えられた役割は、太陽を神格化した天照大神、月を神格化したツクヨミとは少々異なっているため、議論の的となっている。
sen.e: His given role was little different from Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess) who deified sun and Tsukuyomi who deified moon, so it has been the topic of debate.
His given role was little different from that of Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess), who deified the sun, and Tsukuyomi, who deified the moon, so it has been the topic of debate.
His given role was little different from that of Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess), who deified the sun, and Tsukuyomi, who deified the moon, so it has been the topic of debate.

sen.j: 神話での記述
sen.e: Description on mythology
Description in Mythology
Description in mythology
sen.cmt: 文頭以外の語頭大文字を小文字に

sen.j: 『古事記』によれば、神産みにおいてイザナギが黄泉から帰還し、日向橘小門阿波岐原（ひむかのたちばなのをどのあはきはら）で禊を行った際、鼻を濯いだ時に産まれたとする。
sen.e: According to "Kojiki," when Izanagi (The Male Who Invites) came back from Yomi (world after death) for kamiumi (creation of deities) and performed ablutions in Himukano Tachibanano Odono Awakihara, he was born when Izanagi rinsed his nose.

According to "Kojiki," when Izanagi (The Male Who Invites) came back from Yomi (the world after death) for kamiumi (the creation of deities) and performed ablutions in Himukano Tachibanano Odono Awakihara, he was born when Izanagi rinsed his nose.

According to "Kojiki," when Izanagi came back from the world after death for the creation of deities and performed ablutions in Himukano Tachibanano Odono Awakihara, he was born when Izanagi rinsed his nose.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 『日本書紀』ではイザナギとイザナミの間に産まれたとしている。
sen.e: It was described in "Nihonshoki" that he was born between Izanagi and Izanami (The Female Who Invites).
It was described in "Nihon Shoki" that he was born between Izanagi and Izanami (The Female Who Invites).
It was described in "Nihon Shoki" that he was born between Izanagi and Izanami (The Female Who Invites).

sen.j: 統治領域は文献によって異なり、三貴神のうち天照大神は高天原であるが、月夜見尊は滄海原（あおのうなばら）または夜を、スサノオには夜の食国（よるのおすくに）または海原を治めるように言われたとあり、それぞれ異なる。
sen.e: His governing region was different in each literature, and among Sankishi (three deities), Amaterasu Omikami was told to govern Takamanohara, Tsukiyomi no mikoto for Aounahara or night, and Susano for Yoruno Osukuni (a land of night) or ocean.

His governing region varied throughout the literature, but among the Sankishi (three deities) Amaterasu Omikami was told to govern Takamanohara, Tsukiyomi no mikoto for Aounahara or the night, and Susano for Yoruno Osukuni (a land of night) or the ocean.

His governing region varied throughout the literature, but among the Sankishi (three deities) Amaterasu Omikami was told to govern Takamanohara, Tsukiyomi no mikoto to govern the blue-green sea plain or the night, and Susano to govern the land of night or the ocean.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 『古事記』によれば、スサノオはそれを断り、母神イザナミのいる根の国に行きたいと願い、イザナギの怒りを買って追放されてしまう。
sen.e: According to 'Kojiki,' Susano refused it and wished to go to Nenokuni (Land of the Roots) where mother goddess Izanami stayed, but Izanagi got angry about that and expelled him from the land.

According to 'Kojiki,' Susano refused it but instead wanted to go to Nenokuni (Land of the Roots), where the mother goddess Izanami stayed, but Izanagi was angered by that and expelled him from the land.

According to "Kojiki," Susano refused it but instead wanted to go to Nenokuni (Land of the Roots), where the mother goddess Izanami stayed, but Izanagi was angered by that and expelled him from the land.

sen.j: そこでスサノオは根の国へ向う前に姉の天照大神に別れの挨拶をしようと高天原へ上るが、天照大神はスサノオが高天原に攻め入って来たのではと考えて武装してスサノオに応対し、スサノオは疑いを解くためにアマテラスとスサノオの誓約を行う。
sen.e: So, he went up to Takamanohara to say goodbye to his sister Amaterasu Omikami before he left for Nenokuni, but Amaterasu Omikami thought Susano came to attack Takamanohara, so she was armed and dealt with him, and he plighted his faith with Amaterasu to dispel doubts.

So, he went up to Takamanohara in order to say goodbye to his sister, Amaterasu Omikami, before he left for Nenokuni, but Amaterasu Omikami thought Susano had come to attack Takamanohara, so she was armed and dealt with him, and he pleaded his faith with Amaterasu so as to dispel her doubts.

So, he went up to Takamanohara in order to say goodbye to his sister, Amaterasu Omikami, before he left for Nenokuni, but Amaterasu Omikami thought Susano had come to attack Takamanohara, so she was armed and he pleaded his faith with Amaterasu so as to dispel her doubts.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 誓約によって潔白であることが証明されたとしてスサノオは高天原に滞在するが、そこで粗暴な行為をしたので、天照大神は天岩戸に隠れてしまった。
sen.e: His name was cleared by plighting his faith, so Susano stayed Takamanohara, but he behaved rudely there and Amaterasu Omikami hid in Ama no iwato (Cave of heaven).
His name was cleared by pleading his faith, so Susano remained in Takamanohara; but he behaved rudely there and Amaterasu Omikami hid in Ama no iwato (Cave of Heaven).
His name was cleared by pleading his faith, so Susano remained in Takamanohara; but he behaved badly there and Amaterasu Omikami hid in Ama no iwato (Cave of Heaven).
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: そのため、スサノオは高天原を追放されて葦原中国へ降った。
sen.e: Therefore, Susano was expelled from Takamanohara and went down to Ashihara no nakatsukuni.
Therefore, Susano was expelled from Takamanohara and went down to Ashihara no nakatsukuni.
Therefore, Susano was expelled from Takamanohara and went down to Ashihara no nakatsukuni.

sen.j: 葦原中国にある出雲国の鳥髪山（現在の船通山）へ降ったスサノオは、その地を荒らしていたヤマタノオロチ（八俣遠呂智）を退治し、八岐大蛇の尾から出てきた天叢雲剣を天照大神に献上した。
sen.e: When Susano went down to Mt. Torikami (present Mt. Sentsu) of Izumo Province in Ashihara no nakatsukuni, he exterminated Yamatanoorochi (eight-forked-snake) which was devastating the land, and he presented Ama no Murakumo no Tsurugi Sword that came out from the tale of Yamatanoorochi to Amaterasu Omikami.

When Susano went down to Mt. Torikami (now Mt. Sentsu) of Izumo Province, in Ashihara no nakatsukuni, he exterminated Yamatanoorochi (eight-forked snake), which was devastating the land, and to Amaterasu Omikami he presented Ama no Murakumo no Tsurugi Sword (which was derived from the tale of Yamatanoorochi).

When Susano went down to Mt. Torikami (now Mt. Sentsu) of Izumo Province, in Ashihara no nakatsukuni, he exterminated Yamatanoorochi (eight-forked snake), which was devastating the land, and gave Amaterasu Omikami an Ama no Murakumo no Tsurugi Sword (which was derived from the tale of Yamatanoorochi).
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: スサノオは、八岐大蛇に食われることになっていたクシナダヒメを妻として、出雲の須我神社へ行きそこに留まった。
sen.e: Susano went to Suga-jinja Shrine in Izumo by taking Kushinadahime as his wife, who was supposed to be eaten by Yamatanoorochi, and stayed there.
Susano went to Suga-jinja Shrine in Izumo by taking Kushinadahime as his wife, who was supposed to be eaten by Yamatanoorochi, and stayed there.
Susano went to Suga-jinja Shrine in Izumo by taking Kushinadahime as his wife, who was about to be eaten by Yamatanoorochi.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: そこで 八雲立つ出雲八重垣妻籠に八重垣作るその八重垣を と詠んだ。
sen.e: Then he composed a poem, 'Clouds, actively upwelling covered the eightfold fence. It makes the eightfold fence to have my new wife stay in the house. Great eightfold fence.'
sen.cmt: 分かりやすいよう、和歌部分の訳に' 'を付けました。
sen.e: He then composed a poem, 'Clouds, actively upwelling, covered the eightfold fence; it makes the eightfold fence to have my new wife stay in the house; great eightfold fence.'
He then composed a poem, 'Clouds covered the eightfold fence; making the eightfold fence to keep my new wife in the house; great eightfold fence.'
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: （「夜久毛多都伊豆毛夜幣賀岐都麻碁微爾夜幣賀岐都久流曾能夜幣賀岐袁」--『古事記』、「夜句茂多菟伊弩毛夜覇餓岐菟磨語昧爾夜覇餓枳都倶盧贈廼夜覇餓岐廻」--『日本書紀』）これは初の和歌とされる。
sen.e: ('夜久毛多都伊豆毛夜幣賀岐都麻碁微爾夜幣賀岐都久流曾能夜幣賀岐袁'--original text in "Kojiki", '夜句茂多菟伊弩毛夜覇餓岐菟磨語昧爾夜覇餓枳都倶盧贈廼夜覇餓岐廻'--original text in "Nihonshoki") It was estimated to be the first waka.
sen.cmt: すでに現代訳のほうで英訳しているため、古事記や日本書紀などの原文はそのままとしています
sen.e: ('夜久毛多都伊豆毛夜幣賀岐都麻碁微爾夜幣賀岐都久流曾能夜幣賀岐袁'--original text in "Kojiki," '夜句茂多菟伊弩毛夜覇餓岐菟磨語昧爾夜覇餓枳都倶盧贈廼夜覇餓岐廻'--original text in "Nihon Shoki") It was estimated to be the first waka.

('夜久毛多都伊豆毛夜幣賀岐都麻碁微爾夜幣賀岐都久流曾能夜幣賀岐袁,' original text in "Kojiki," '夜句茂多菟伊弩毛夜覇餓岐菟磨語昧爾夜覇餓枳都倶盧贈廼夜覇餓岐廻,' original text in "Nihon Shoki") It was estimated to be the first waka (a traditional Japanese poem of thirty-one syllables).
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。原文の意味が確認できませんでしたが、上記で意味を説明しているため、一部原文のまま表示しました。半角カッコにし、クォーテーションに変えました。

sen.j: また、ここから「八雲」は出雲を象徴する言葉ともなった。
sen.e: From that, 'Yakumo' became the word to symbolize Izumo.
From that, 'Yakumo' became the word that symbolized Izumo.
From that, 'Yakumo' became the word that symbolized Izumo.

sen.j: その地で大国主などを産ませ（『日本書紀』では大已貴神（おおあなむちのかみ）。
sen.e: Susano have his wife give birth to Okuninushi (chief god of Izumo in southern Honshu Island, Japan, and the central character in the important cycle of myths set in that region) (named Ooanamuchi no Kami in "Nihonshoki").

Susano had his wife give birth to Okuninushi (chief god of Izumo in southern Honshu Island, Japan, and the central character in the important cycle of myths set in that region) (called Ooanamuchi no Kami in "Nihon Shoki").

Susano had his wife give birth to Okuninushi (chief god of Izumo in southern Honshu Island, Japan, and the central character in the important myths of that region) (called Oanamuchi no Kami in "Nihon Shoki").
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 『古事記』では大国主命はスサノオの6代後の子孫としている）、その後、根の国へ向かったと言う。
sen.e: In "Kojiki," Okuninushi no mikoto was a descendant after six generation of Susano, and he went to Nenokuni afterward.
In "Kojiki," Okuninushi no mikoto was a descendant after the sixth generation of Susano, and eventually he went to Nenokuni.
In "Kojiki," Okuninushi no mikoto was a descendant after the sixth generation of Susano, and eventually he went to Nenokuni (underworld).
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 『日本書紀』における八岐大蛇の記述がある一書第4では、天から追放されたスサノオは、新羅の蘇志摩利そしもりに降りた。
sen.e: In the fourth section of the first book which described Yamatanoorochi in "Nihonshoki," Susano, who was expelled from Takamanohara, went down to Soshimari (Shoshimori) in Shiragi.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In the fourth section of the first book, which described Yamatanoorochi in "Nihon Shoki," Susano, who had been expelled from Takamanohara, went down to Soshimari (Shoshimori) in Shiragi.
In the fourth section of the first book, which described Yamatanoorochi in "Nihon Shoki," Susano, who had been expelled from Takamanohara, went down to Soshimari (Shoshimori) in Shiragi.

sen.j: この地吾居ること欲さず「乃興言曰 此地吾不欲居」と言い息子の五十猛神（イソタケル）と共に土船で東に渡り出雲国斐伊川上の鳥上の峰へ到った（「遂以埴土作舟 乘之東渡 到出雲國簸川上所在 鳥上之峯」）後八岐大蛇を退治した。
sen.e: Susano did not want to stay there, so he said 'I do not want to stay here'('乃興言曰 此地吾不欲居' --original text) and took his son Isotakerunokami to the east by tsuchibune (ship to carry sediment) and reached Torigami no Mine (Range) on the upper Hi-kawa River in Izumo Province('遂以埴土作舟 乘之東渡 到出雲國簸川上所在 鳥上之峯'--original text), and then he exterminated Yamatanoorochi.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処（）内の原文はすでに現代訳のほうで英訳しているため、そのまま表記しています
sen.e: Susano didn't want to stay there, so he said 'I do not want to stay here' ('乃興言曰 此地吾不欲居' --original text) and took his son Isotakerunokami to the east by tsuchibune (a ship used to carry sediment) and reached the Torigami no Mine (Range) on the upper Hi-kawa River in Izumo Province('遂以埴土作舟 乘之東渡 到出雲國簸川上所在 鳥上之峯'--original text), whereupon he exterminated Yamatanoorochi.

Susano didn't want to stay there, so he said 'I do not want to stay here' ('乃興言曰 此地吾不欲居' --original text) and took his son Isotakerunokami to the east by tsuchibune (a ship used to carry sediment) and reached the Torigami no Mine (Range) on the upper Hii-kawa River in Izumo Province('遂以埴土作舟 乘之東渡 到出雲國簸川上所在 鳥上之峯'--original text), whereupon he exterminated Yamatanoorochi.

sen.j: そのとき五十猛神が天から持ち帰った木々の種を、韓（から、朝鮮）の地には植えず、八島（おおやしま、本州のこと）に植えたので、大八州は山の地になったと言う。
sen.e: At that time, he did not plant the seeds of trees, which Isotakerunokami brought back from the heaven, on Kara (the old Korea) and planted on Yashima (also known as Oyashima, Honshu (the main island of Japan)), and Oyashima became the land of mountains.

At that time he didn't plant the seeds of trees, which Isotakerunokami had brought back from the heavens, on Kara (the old Korea) and planted on Yashima (also known as Oyashima, Honshu (the main island of Japan)), and Oyashima became the land of mountains.

At that time he didn't plant the seeds of trees, which Isotakerunokami had brought back from the heavens, in Kara (the old Korea) and planted them in Yashima (also known as Oyashima, Honshu (the main island of Japan)), and Oyashima became the land of mountains.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: また続く一書第5では、木がないと子が困るだろうと言い、体毛を抜いて木に変え、種類ごとに用途を定め、息子の五十猛命、娘の大屋都比賣神、抓津姫神 に命じて全国に植えさせたという。
sen.e: Also, in the fifth section of the first book, he said that children would be stranded without trees, he changed his skin hair into trees, established the usage for each kind, and ordered his son Isotakeru and his daughter Tsumatsuhime to plant the trees.

Also, in the fifth section of the first book he said that children would be stranded without trees; he changed his skin hair into trees, established the usage for each kind, and ordered his son Isotakeru and his daughter Tsumatsuhime to plant the trees.

Also, in the fifth section of the first book he said that children would be in trouble without trees; so he changed his skin hair into trees, established the usage for each kind, and ordered his son Isotakeru and his daughters Oyatsuhime and Tsumatsuhime to plant the trees.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 大国主の神話において根の国のスサノオの元にやってきたオオナムヂ（大国主）は、スサノオの娘であるスセリビメに一目惚れするが、スサノオはオオナムヂに様々な試練を与える。
sen.e: On the mythology of Okuninushi, Onamuji (Okuninushi) who came to Susano in Nenokuni fell in love with Suseri-bime, Susano's daughter, at first sight, but Susano gave Onamuji various trials.
In the mythology of Okuninushi, Onamuji (Okuninushi), who came to Susano in Nenokuni, fell in love with Suseri-bime, Susano's daughter, at first sight, but Susano set various trials before Onamuji.

In the mythology of Okuninushi, Onamuji (Okuninushi), who came to Susano in Nenokuni (the underworld), fell in love with Suseri-bime, Susano's daughter, at first sight, but Susano set various trials before Onamuji.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: オオナムヂはそれを克服し、スサノオはオオナムヂがスセリビメを妻とすることを認め、オオナムヂに大国主という名を贈った。
sen.e: Onamuji overcame those trials and Susano accepted Onamuji to take Suseri-bime as his wife and sent Onamuji a name of Okuninushi.
Onamuji overcame those trials and Susano accepted Onamuji's right to take Suseri-bime as his wife, whereupon he sent Onamuji the name of Okuninushi.
Onamuji overcame those trials and Susano accepted Onamuji's right to take Suseri-bime as his wife, whereupon he gave Onamuji the name of Okuninushi.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 解説
sen.e: Description
Description
Explanation

sen.j: スサノオの性格は多面的である。
sen.e: Susano had many faces.
Susano had many faces.
Susano had many faces.

sen.j: 母の国へ行きたいと言って泣き叫ぶ子供のような一面があるかと思えば、高天原では凶暴な一面を見せる。
sen.e: He had one side to scream like a kid to go to her mother's land but he also showed the brutish side in Takamanohara.
One one hand, he could scream like a child in order to go to his mother's land, but he also showed a brutish side in Takamanohara.
On one hand, he could scream like a child in order to go to his mother's land, but he also showed a brutish side in Takamanohara.

sen.j: 出雲へ降りると一転して貴種流離譚のヒーロー的な性格となる。
sen.e: When he came down to Izumo, he suddenly changed to the hero character of Kishuryuri-tan (a type of folktales that those like young deity or nobility get over trials to be a god or a blessed).

When he came down to Izumo, he suddenly changed to the hero character of Kishuryuri-tan (a type of folktale in which a character such as a young deity or nobility overcomes trials in order to be a god or be blessed).

When he came down to Izumo, he suddenly changed to the hero character of Kishuryuri-tan (a type of folktale in which a character such as a young deity or nobility overcomes trials in order to be a god or be blessed).

sen.j: ヤマタノオロチ退治の英雄譚は優秀な産鉄民を平定した象徴と見る説も根強く、天叢雲剣の取得はその象徴であるとの解釈も多い。
sen.e: There was a persistent theory that Eiyutan (a story to describe a hero's success) of Yamatanoorochi's extermination was a symbol to subjugate excellent Santetsumin (people who had technique to make iron), and many people believed that getting the Ama no Murakumo no Tsurugi Sword was a symbol of that.

There was a persistent theory that the Eiyutan (a story told to describe a hero's success) of Yamatanoorochi's extermination was a symbol to subjugate the excellent Santetsumin (people who had technology for iron-making), and many people believed that attaining the Ama no Murakumo no Tsurugi Sword was symbolic of that.

There was a theory that the Eiyutan (a story told to describe a hero's success) of Yamatanoorochi's extermination was a symbol to subjugate the clever Santetsumin (people who had technology for iron-making), and many people believed that attaining the Ama no Murakumo no Tsurugi Sword was symbolic of that.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: しかし、日本初の和歌を詠んだり、木の用途を定めたりなど文化英雄的な側面もある。
sen.e: However, there was a side of cultural hero such as composing the first waka in Japan and establishing the usage of trees.
However, there was the aspect of cultural heroism, such as composing the first waka in Japan and establishing the usage of trees.
Susano showed a cultivated side, composing the first waka in Japan and utilizing trees for woodcraft or architecture.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: これは、多数の神が習合してスサノオという神格が創造されたためとする説もあるが、スサノオが成長するにつれて見せる側面であるとする説もある。
sen.e: There was a theory that this was because Susano was created by getting many deities together, but some say it was a side that Susano showed as he grew.
It has been theorized that this was because Susano was created by gathering many deities together, but some say it was a side that Susano showed as he grew.
Some say that this was because Susano was created by an amalgamation of many gods, and other theories suggest this was a side of Susano that appeared as he grew.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 神名の「スサ」は、荒れすさぶの意として嵐の神、暴風雨の神とする説や（高天原でのスサノオの行いは暴風雨の被害を示すとする）、「進む」と同根で勢いのままに事を行うの意とする説がある。
sen.e: There were some theories on his Shinmyo 'Susa' that it came from God of Storm, or God of Rainstorm (Susano's activities in Takamanohara indicated the damage by rainstorm) as the meaning of Aresusabu (rough), or it meant act on the momentum with the same root as 'susumu (progress).'
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: There were some theories regarding his Shinmyo 'Susa,' which asserted that it came from the god of storms or the god of rainstorms (Susano's activities in Takamanohara indicated the damage by rainstorms) as the meaning of Aresusabu (rough); or that it meant acting on the momentum, having the same root as 'susumu (progress).'

There were some theories regarding his deity name of 'Susa,' which asserted that it came from the god of storms or the god of rainstorms (Susano's activities in Takamanohara indicated the damage by rainstorms) or that it meant acting on the momentum, having the same root as 'susumu' (progress).
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。クォーテーションの位置を変えました。

sen.j: また、出雲の須佐神社 (出雲市)（現在の島根県出雲市須佐神社 (出雲市)）に因むとする説（スサノオは須佐郷の族長を神格化したものとする）、州砂(砂鉄)の王という説から、意宇郡(おうのこおり)の首長とする説などがある。
sen.e: Also, another theory was that it was connected with Susa-jinja Shrine in Izumo (present Susa-jinja Shrine in Izumo City, Shimane Prefecture) (Susano was created by deifying the head of Susa-go), or it was from the king of iron sand or from the chief of O county.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「州砂」の意味が見つからなかったため、「砂鉄」のみ訳出しました。
sen.e: Another theory was that it was connected to Susa-jinja Shrine in Izumo (the present-day Susa-jinja Shrine in Izumo City, Shimane Prefecture) (Susano was created by deifying the head of Susa-go), or that it was from the king of iron sand or the chief of O County.

Another theory was that it was derived from Susa-jinja Shrine in Izumo (the present-day Susa-jinja Shrine in Izumo City, Shimane Prefecture) (Susano was created by deifying the head of Susa-go), or that it was from the king of iron sand or the chief of O County.
sen.cmt: king of iron sand?FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 記紀神話においては出雲の神の祖神として書かれているスサノオであるが、『出雲国風土記』ではスサノオはあまり登場せず、意宇郡安来郷や飯石郡（いいしのこおり）須佐郷などの地名制定や御子神たちの説話が書かれており、ヤマタノオロチ退治の説話は記載されていない。
sen.e: On Kiki-shinwa (the Kojiki, Nihonshoki and mythology), Susano was described as a soshin (ancestor honored as god) of god in Izumo, but he did not appear much in "Izumo no kuni fudoki" (Fudoki of Izumo no kuni), the toponym system like Yasugi-go in O county and Susa-go in Iishi county and setsuwa (anecdotes) of mikogami (the child god in a shrine where parent-child gods are enshrined) were written, and setsuwa of exterminating Yamatanoorochi was not written.

In Kiki-shinwa (the Kojiki, Nihon Shoki and mythology), Susano was described as a soshin (an ancestor honored as a god) of a god in Izumo, but he did not appear much in "Izumo no kuni fudoki" (Fudoki of Izumo no kuni), the toponym system like that of Yasugi-go in O County and Susa-go in Iishi County and the setsuwa (anecdotes) in which the mikogami (the child gods in a shrine where parent-child gods are enshrined); however, the setsuwa of exterminating Yamatanoorochi was not written.

In Kiki-shinwa (the mythology of the Kojiki and Nihon Shoki), Susano was described as being a soshin (an ancestor worshipped as a deity) of a god from the Izumo region, but he received little mention in the "Izumo no kuni fudoki" (the topography of Izumo Province), which provided descriptions of place name systems such as those of Yasugi-go in O County and Susa-go in Iishi County and setsuwa (anecdotes) concerning the mikogami (the child gods in a shrine where parent-child gods are enshrined) so anecdotes concerning the slaying of Yamata no Orochi were not included.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。クォーテーション、スペルを変え、用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: そのため元々は別の地方の神ではないかとする説もあり、その地として、以下のような説がある。
sen.e: Therefore, some say he might originally be a god in another area, and possible areas were as follows.
Therefore, some say he might have originally been a god in another area, and the possible areas are as follows.
Therefore, some say he might have originally been a god in another area, and the possible areas are as follows.

sen.j: 日本書紀の一書でヤマタノオロチ退治が行われたとする備中国とする説
sen.e: It might be Bicchu Province where Yamatanoorochi was exterminated, described in Nihonshoki.
It might be Bicchu Province, where Yamatanoorochi was exterminated, as described in Nihon Shoki.
There is a theory that it might be Bitchu Province, where Yamatanoorochi was exterminated, as described in Nihon Shoki.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。表記を変えました。

sen.j: 大国主がスサノオのいる根の国へ行く前に「木の国」へ行っていること、子のイソタケルが祀られているとしていることなどから紀伊国（熊野三山）とする説
sen.e: It might be Kii Province (Kumano Sanzan (three major shrines, Kumano-Hongu-Taisha, Kumano-Hayatama-Taisha and Kumano-Nachi-Taisha)) since Okuninushi went to 'Kinokuni (Land of trees)' before he went to Susano in Nenokuni and his son Isotakeru was enshrined.

It might be Kii Province (Kumano Sanzan (three major shrines: Kumano-Hongu-Taisha, Kumano-Hayatama-Taisha and Kumano-Nachi-Taisha)), since Okuninushi went to 'Kinokuni (Land of Trees)' before he went to Susano in Nenokuni and his son Isotakeru was enshrined.
It might be Kii Province since Okuninushi went to 'Kinokuni' (Land of Trees) before he went to Susano in Nenokuni and his son Isotakeru was enshrined.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。クォーテーションの位置を変えました。

sen.j: 日本書紀一書第4のまず新羅の曽尸茂梨に天降ってから出雲の鳥上峯に来たとの記述から、新羅の神とする説
sen.e: It might be Shiragi since it was written in the fourth section of the first book in Nihonshoki that he first went down to Soshimori in Shiragi, then came to Torigami no Mine in Izumo.
It might be Shiragi, since it was written in the fourth section of the first book in Nihon Shoki that he first went down to Soshimori in Shiragi and then came to Torigami no Mine in Izumo.

There is a theory that it might be Shiragi, since it was written in the fourth section of the first book in Nihon Shoki that he first went down to Soshimori in Shiragi and then came to Torigami no Mine in Izumo.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: しかし、基本的には記紀、風土記をそれぞれ眺めると出雲との結びつきが強い神といえる。
sen.e: However, it could be said that he basically had strong ties with Izumo by looking at Kiki and Fudoki.
However, it could be said that he basically developed strong ties with Izumo by looking at Kiki and Fudoki.
However, it could be said that he basically developed strong ties with Izumo by looking at the historical records called Kiki and Fudoki.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 出雲国(現；島根県)東部の奥出雲町にはスサノオが降臨したといわれる鳥髪峰(現；船通山)、それに隣接する安来市はスサノオが地名をつけたという風土記の記述もある。
sen.e: There is Mt. Torikami (present Mt. Sentsu) in Okuizumo-cho in the east side of Izumo Province (present Shimane Prefecture), where Susano was descended, and it was written in Fudoki that Susano named its neighboring Yasugi City.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: There is Mt. Torikami (now Mt. Sentsu) in Okuizumo-cho, in the east side of Izumo Province (the present-day Shimane Prefecture), to which Susano descended, and it was written in Fudoki that Susano named its neighboring Yasugi City.

There is Mt. Torikami (now Mt. Sentsu) in Okuizumo-cho on the east side of Izumo Province (the present-day Shimane Prefecture), to which Susano descended, and it was written in Fudoki (ancient record) that Susano named the neighboring city, Yasugi City.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: これらの地域が古代より踏鞴製鉄が盛んであったこともあいまって、オロチ退治は製鉄集団を統治したとの見方も強い。
sen.e: These areas were caught on tatara iron making method from ancient times, and together with that, it was widely thought that he governed iron making group by exterminating Yamatanoorochi.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: These areas had caught onto the tatara iron-making method in ancient times, and it was widely thought that he governed the iron-making group by exterminating Yamatanoorochi.

These areas had developed the tatara iron-making method in ancient times, and it was widely thought that this meant that Susano established his rule over the iron-making group by slaying Yamata no Orochi.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: また比較神話学的にみると、怪物を倒して鉄や剣を手に入れる神話は国家樹立の比喩であるとする見方もある。
sen.e: By comparative mythology, the mythology to get iron and sword by exterminating a monster thought to be a metaphor for establishment of a nation.
Based on comparative mythology, the mythology of obtaining iron and a sword by exterminating a monster is thought to be a metaphor for the establishment of a nation.
Based on comparative mythology, the mythology of obtaining iron and a sword by exterminating a monster is thought to be a metaphor for the establishment of a nation.

sen.j: スサノオをアマテラスの弟という重要な神とされている理由についても諸説ある。
sen.e: There are various theories on the reasons that Susano was the important god as he was a brother of Amaterasu.
There are various theories on the reasons that Susano was the important god, since he was a brother of Amaterasu.
There are various theories as to why Susano was thought to be a younger brother of Amaterasu and an important god.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 後に、仏教における祇園精舎の守護神である牛頭天王と神仏習合した。
sen.e: Later, he had syncretization of Shinto with Buddhism with Gozu Tenno (deity said to be the Indian god Gavagriva) who was a guardian god of Jetavana Vihara under Buddhism.
Later, he had the syncretization of Shinto with Buddhism with Gozu Tenno (a deity said to be the Indian god Gavagriva), who was a guardian god of Jetavana Vihara under Buddhism.
Later, he became combined with Gozu Tenno (a deity said to be the Indian god Gavagriva), who was a guardian god of Jetavana Vihara under Buddhism.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。 withを削除しました。

sen.j: これは、どちらも災疫をもたらす神だからである。
sen.e: It was because both gods delivered disaster and epidemic.
It was because both gods delivered disasters and epidemics.
It was because both gods delivered disasters and epidemics.

sen.j: 三貴子（サンキシ）と呼ばれるイザナギ最後の子の三神、つまりアマテラス・ツクヨミ・スサノオのうちで、記述によって共通であるのはアマテラス＝太陽のみで、ツクヨミとスサノオは書物によって統治領域が重なる場合がある。
sen.e: Within three deities of Izanagi's last children, called Sankishi, in other words, Amaterasu, Tsukuyomi, and Susano, common description was Amaterasu equals to sun only, and there was a case where governing regions of Tsukuyomi and Susano overlapped depending on the literature.

Within the three deities of Izanagi's last children, called Sankishi (in other words, Amaterasu, Tsukuyomi and Susano) the common description was that Amaterasu equaled the sun only, and there was a case where the governing regions of Tsukuyomi and Susano overlapped, depending on the literature.

Among the three deities of Izanagi's last children, called Sankishi (in other words, Amaterasu, Tsukuyomi and Susano) the common description was that Amaterasu equaled the sun only, and there was a case where the governing regions of Tsukuyomi and Susano overlapped, depending on the literature.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: ツクヨミとスサノオが共に海原の神であるのは、太古においてわが国に文化を開いた縄文人たちから伝わる朧な記憶の伝達であるのかもしれない。
sen.e: Both Tsukuyomi and Susano were the deities of ocean because it was the transfer of dim memory from Jomon men who produced culture in our country in ancient times.
Both Tsukuyomi and Susano were deities of the ocean because it was the transfer of vague memory from the Jomon men, who produced culture in our country in ancient times.
Both Tsukuyomi and Susano were deities of the ocean and this myth was a legacy of the Jomon period.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 海上をゆく航海者は夜の月で時を測り、良風を願って海原の神に祈願したのかもしれない。
sen.e: Voyagers sailing in the sea calculated the time by the night moon and might have prayed for the deities of ocean wishing for favorable winds.
Voyagers sailing in the sea calculated the time by the night moon and might have prayed to the ocean deities, wishing for favorable winds.
Voyagers sailing in the sea calculated the time by the night moon and prayed to the ocean deities, wishing for favorable winds.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: しかし時代がたつにつれ、神格は分かれ、航海者の記憶は薄れると共に、統治領域についても曖昧になり、やがてそれぞれ独立した存在となったのかもしれない。
sen.e: However, divinities were divided, memory of voyagers receded, and governing regions became ambiguous, then each became independent entity with time.
However, divinities were divided, the voyagers' memories receded and governing regions became ambiguous, so that over time each became an independent entity.
However over time, as the seafarers memories became vague along with the boundaries of governing regions, these deities became separate entities.
sen.cmt: 意味不明FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: これらの神社は、祇園社や天王社を名乗ったものが明治の神仏分離の際に現在の名前になったものが多い。
sen.e: Many of these shrines used the names of Gion-sha Shrine and Tenno-sha Shrine but renamed as current name at the time of separation of Buddhism and Shintoism in Meiji period.
Many of these shrines used the names of Gion-sha Shrine and Tenno-sha Shrine but were given their present names upon the separation of Buddhism and Shintoism in the Meiji period.
Many of these shrines used the names of Gion-sha Shrine and Tenno-sha Shrine but were given their present names upon the separation of Buddhism and Shintoism in the Meiji period.

sen.e: Suga(須賀)-jinja Shrine, Suga(須我)-jinja Shrine, Suga(素鵞)-jinja Shrine
sen.cmt: 漢字違いで同じ読み方の名前には、（）内に漢字を入れました。「曖昧さ回避」の意味が明確に解釈できませんでしたが、直訳してみました。
sen.e: Suga (須賀)-jinja Shrine, Suga (須我)-jinja Shrine, Suga (素鵞)-jinja Shrine
Suga (須賀)-jinja Shrine, Suga (須我)-jinja Shrine, Suga (素鵞)-jinja Shrine

sen.j: 氷川神社 (曖昧さ回避)、簸川神社
